questions.title: Question 1
questions.text:
Given the decline in vision, an OCT macula OS was performed below:

![](/content/media/retina-9-2.webp)

What pathology is NOT present in the OCT shown to the left?

answers.explanation:
The Diagnosis is Optic Pit Maculopathy.

![](/content/media/retina-9-3.webp)

Congenital optic pits are excavations of the optic nerve head secondary to malformation of the optic nerve during early development. It can be complicated by macular edema, schisis, or serous retinal detachment. In this patient, the most noticeable abnormality on the OCT is subretinal fluid that tracks from the optic nerve to involve the macula. When examining a patient with subretinal fluid involving the macula, it is important to rule out optic pit as a potential cause. Majority of optic pits can be found temporally.

The fundus photograph is labelled: The black arrow is pointing towards the optic pit, and the yellow arrow is pointing towards the edge of the subretinal fluid.

questions.title: Question 3
questions.text: What is the management for this diagnosis?

answers.explanation:
![](/content/media/retina-9-2.webp)

There is no clear consensus regarding treatment of optic pit maculopathy. There is no evidence for anti-VEGF therapy for treatment of optic pits. Conservative management would not be appropriate given the vision of 20/200 and the associated risk of amblyopia in the pediatric population. The most commonly used intervention for the treatment of optic pit maculopathy is pars plana vitrectomy (PPV).

title: Case 9
description: 5M presenting with 3-months of worsening vision OS
patientPresentation:
A 5-year-old male presents with a 3-month history of gradually worsening vision in his left eye. Vision was 20/25 OD and 20/200 OS. There was no RAPD. The patient denied any recent history of ocular trauma and is otherwise healthy. There was a vague maternal family history of retinal detachment. The patient's fundus photograph is shown below:

### Learning Objectives:

1. Recognize features of optic pit maculopathy, which include subretinal fluid, macular edema, and retinoschisis on OCT.
2. Understand the importance of examining the optic nerve head carefully for optic pits when assessing a patient with subretinal fluid involving the macula.
